metadata.case_name: Hindustan Lever Ltd. v. Mazdoor Sabha
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 675 to 681 of 1967 and Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1971

facts.text: Hindustan Lever Ltd. Calcutta Branch concerned only with marketing.
From 1956, marketing organisation in three divisions: Soaps Division, Foods Division, Toilet Preparations Division.
On 6-9-1966, company reorganised marketing into two divisions: Main Lines Division and Speciality Lines Division.

On 30-9-1966, Government of West Bengal referred to Third Industrial Tribunal: 'Is the human rationalisation as a measure of economic reorganisation of the Company reflected through job-integration that have either been effected or proposed to be effected justified? To what relief, if any, are the workmen entitled?'
Pending adjudication, seven workers filed applications under section 33A alleging adverse change in service conditions and non-payment of salary for October 1966.
Tribunal award dated 23-3-1967 in favour of workers in s.33A cases (Misc. Cases Nos. 161, 160, 162-64 and 167 of 1966).
Employer filed appeals by special leave: Civil Appeals Nos. 675 to 681 of 1967.
Main reference disposed on 11-8-1969 by Tribunal in favour of employer (Case No. VIII-373 of 1966, published Calcutta Gazette 27-9-1969).
Workers filed Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1971 by special leave.
Different Presiding Officers in two proceedings.
Vast evidence by employer in main reference led to finding in its favour; meagre evidence in s.33A cases led to finding for workers.
Reorganisation involved regrouping products, redeployment of sales management staff on geographical basis, reorganisation of trade outlets, redeployment of sales force over two product groups.
No retrenchment resulted from reorganisation; employer assured no retrenchment during negotiations.
Voluntary retirements and non-filling of vacancies occurred, but not retrenchment as defined in s.2(oo).
Salesmen handled products of more than one division since 1960 in joint selling; integrated selling in Assam since 1964.
Journey cycles increased from 4 weeks to 6.5 weeks; three godowns reduced to two.
Workers refused to work under new scheme, offered to work under old; management refused work and wages for October 1966.
Prolonged consultations between parties before reorganisation.

legal_issues.text: Whether reorganisation required notice under s.9A of Industrial Disputes Act (items 8, 10, 11 of Fourth Schedule).
Whether non-payment of wages for October 1966 amounted to alteration of service conditions under s.33A during pendency of reference.
Whether workers' refusal to work under new scheme was justified.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reorganisation did not attract items 8,10,11 Sch IV; no notice u/s 9A required as no retrenchment, no adverse change in conditions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.9A Industrial Disputes Act; Parry & Co. case

petitioner_arguments.text: Non-payment of wages not alteration of service conditions; remedy u/s 33C, not 33A; scheme introduced before reference.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33A, s.33C; North Brooke Jute Co.; National Coal Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prolonged discussions amounted to substantial compliance with s.9A.
Employer has right to reorganise business.

respondent_arguments.text: Reorganisation attracted items 8,10,11 Sch IV (change in usage, rationalisation likely to lead to retrenchment, reduction in departments); notice u/s 9A required.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.9A, Sch IV items 8,10,11; North Brooke Jute Co.

respondent_arguments.text: Increased workload, journey cycles from 4 to 6.5 weeks, godowns from 3 to 2; apprehension of retrenchment justified refusal to work.
Non-payment of wages altered service conditions to prejudice during pendency.
Condition of service to work for one division only.

court_reasoning.text: Different evidence in two proceedings; cannot consider main reference evidence in s.33A appeals.
Reorganisation not under item 10 unless likely to lead to retrenchment; no retrenchment occurred, voluntary retirements not covered.
No adverse effect shown for items 8,11; employer right to organise work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No change in usage adversely affecting workers.

court_reasoning.text: No change in terms/conditions of service; s.9A not attracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Depends on facts; Tribunal findings upheld.

court_reasoning.text: Non-payment of wages is alteration of service conditions if workers justified in refusing new scheme; in s.33A cases, Tribunal found prejudice and surplus staff, justifying refusal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment of wages essential condition of service.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme before reference does not bar s.33A as cause arises de die in diem.
Will not reassess evidence under Art.136 unless perverse.

holdings.text: Reorganisation did not require notice u/s 9A; no change in service conditions to prejudice.
Non-payment of wages amounted to alteration u/s 33A where workers justified in refusal due to lack of notice.
Both Tribunal awards upheld based on evidence in each.

outcome.summary: Both Tribunal awards upheld: s.33A award in favour of workers due to limited evidence showing prejudice; main award in favour of employer due to extensive evidence showing no adverse change or retrenchment. All appeals dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Workers entitled to wages for October 1966 in s.33A cases; reorganisation scheme upheld.

key_quotes.text: This Court in considering a matter under Article 136 does not ordinarily re-assess the evidence on the basis of which the Tribunal came to its conclusions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of interference with Tribunal findings.

key_quotes.text: Payment of wages, is one of the most important among the workers conditions of service. The worker works essentially only for the wages to be paid to him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes non-payment as alteration of service conditions.

key_quotes.text: The employer has got the right to organise his work in the manner he pleases.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms management's prerogative subject to s.9A.

key_quotes.text: Rationalisation or standardisation by itself would not fall under item 10 unless it is likely to lead to retrenchment of workmen.
key_quotes.speaker: court
